perturbation.original_text: 4.1 The Company will pay the Professional a base fee of thirty-six thousand dollars ($36,000) per year (the "Base Fee") for Services performed during the Term. The Company shall pay the Base Fee in four (4) equal installments of nine thousand dollars ($9,000) each on March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year during the Term commencing on January 15, 2000. The Professional acknowledges that the Company is under no obligation to create or maintain the Products. The Professional agrees that payment of the Base Fee shall satisfy all obligations of the Company hereunder if it elects not to create or market and sell the Products.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.1 The Company will pay the Professional a base fee of thirty-six thousand dollars ($36,000) per year (the "Base Fee") for Services performed during the Term. The Company shall pay the Base Fee in four (4) equal installments of nine thousand dollars ($9,000) each on March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year during the Term commencing on January 15, 2000. The Professional acknowledges that the Company is under no obligation to create or maintain the Products. The Professional agrees that payment of the Base Fee shall satisfy all obligations of the Company hereunder regardless if it elects not to create or market and sell the Products. However, if the Company fails to create or market any product, the base fee is reduced to $18,000 per year.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding the Base Fee. The original text states the $36,000 base fee satisfies all obligations even if no product is created. The modified text introduces a condition where the base fee is reduced to $18,000 if no products are created, thus conflicting with the initial statement.

perturbation.original_text: 4.2 If the Company elects to create and market the Products, the Company will pay to the Professional a "Royalty Fee" on the sales of Products during the Term, except as provided in the following sentence, of two percent (2%) of the "Royalty Base," which Royalty Base shall be calculated as the wholesale selling price of all Products for which the Company actually receives the proceeds of such net of returns, allowances, discounts, shipping, taxes, insurance and credits. During the Term, the Company shall pay the Royalty Fee, earned for the preceding quarter, to the Professional quarterly, within thirty (30) days of the end of the succeeding calendar year quarter. If the Company decides not to renew this Agreement in accordance with the provisions of Section 8 below, the Company shall pay the Professional an amount equal to two percent (2%) of the net book value of its unsold inventory of Products on December 31, 2004.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.2 If the Company elects to create and market the Products, the Company will pay to the Professional a "Royalty Fee" on the sales of Products during the Term, except as provided in the following sentence, of two percent (2%) of the "Royalty Base," which Royalty Base shall be calculated as the wholesale selling price of all Products for which the Company actually receives the proceeds of such net of returns, allowances, discounts, shipping, taxes, insurance and credits. During the Term, the Company shall pay the Royalty Fee, earned for the preceding quarter, to the Professional quarterly, within ninety (90) days of the end of the succeeding calendar year quarter. If the Company decides not to renew this Agreement in accordance with the provisions of Section 8 below, the Company shall pay the Professional an amount equal to five percent (5%) of the net book value of its unsold inventory of Products on December 31, 2004.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces conflicting deadlines for Royalty Fee payments and the final payment. The original text states royalty fees are paid within 'thirty (30) days' but the modified text changes it to 'ninety (90) days'. Also the original text states an amount equal to 'two percent (2%)' of net book value, but the modified text changes it to 'five percent (5%)'.

perturbation.original_text: 4.3 If the Company elects to create and market the Products, the Company will grant to the Professional options to purchase shares of the Company's capital stock ("Options"), as provided in this paragraph. On each March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31 during the Term that the Company elects to continue the marketing and sale of the Products, the Company will grant to the Professional a number of Options (the "Quarterly Grant Number"). The Quarterly Grant Number shall be the nearest whole number that results from the division of the number of dollars represented by one half of one percent (0.5%) of the Royalty Base by the closing price of the Company's stock on the grant date. The exercise price of the Options shall be the closing price of the Company stock on the grant date. The sum of the Quarterly Grant Numbers in each calendar year of the Term shall not exceed fifteen thousand (15,000). The options will expire five (5) years after each grant date. The Options shall not be assigned, transferred or alienated by the Professional. Any attempt to assign, transfer or alienate the Options without the prior written consent of the Company shall be void.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.3 If the Company elects to create and market the Products, the Company will grant to the Professional options to purchase shares of the Company's capital stock ("Options"), as provided in this paragraph. On each March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31 during the Term that the Company elects to continue the marketing and sale of the Products, the Company will grant to the Professional a number of Options (the "Quarterly Grant Number"). The Quarterly Grant Number shall be the nearest whole number that results from the division of the number of dollars represented by one half of one percent (0.5%) of the Royalty Base by the closing price of the Company's stock on the grant date. The exercise price of the Options shall be ten percent (10%) below the closing price of the Company stock on the grant date. The sum of the Quarterly Grant Numbers in each calendar year of the Term shall not exceed twenty five thousand (25,000). The options will expire two (2) years after each grant date. The Options shall not be assigned, transferred or alienated by the Professional. Any attempt to assign, transfer or alienate the Options without any consent of the Company shall be allowed.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces multiple contradictions related to stock options. It modifies the exercise price of the options to be 'ten percent (10%) below' closing price instead of 'the closing price' of the stock. The limit on the number of options is increased from 'fifteen thousand (15,000)' to 'twenty five thousand (25,000)'. The option expiry is reduced from 'five (5) years' to 'two (2) years'. Finally, it alters the assignability of options, stating any attempt to assign without consent 'shall be allowed' rather than 'shall be void', contradicting the original clause.
